facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 253 to 255 of 1955 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals-Nos.253 to 255 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and decree dated November 30, 1954 of the former Nagpur High Court in Misc. Petitions Nos. 245, 279 and 308 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decree dated November 30, 1954, of the former Nagpur High Court in Misc. Petitions Nos. 245, 279 and 308 of 1954.

facts.text: The judgment was delivered on April 3, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. April 3.

facts.text: Appellants filed writ applications impugning validity of provisions of Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 imposing sales tax on materials used in construction works.

anchor.surface_text: These are appeals against the judgment of the High Court of Nagpur in writ applications filed by the appellants impugning the validity of certain provisions of the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947  C. Berar 21 of 1947 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, imposing sales tax on materials used in companystruction works.

facts.text: Appellant in Civil Appeal No. 253 of 1955 is a contractor doing business in the construction of buildings and roads for the Military and Public Works Department in the State of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in Civil Appeal No. 253 of 1955 is a companytractor doing business in the companystruction of buildings and roads for the Military and Public Works Department in the State of Madhya Pradesh, and he filed M. P. No. 245 of 1954 challenging the validity of the assessment which the respondents proposed to make,

facts.text: Appellant in CA 253 filed M.P. No. 245 of 1954 challenging proposed assessment.

anchor.surface_text: and he filed M. P. No. 245 of 1954 challenging the validity of the assessment which the respondents proposed to make, on two grounds.

facts.text: Authorities under the Act called upon contractors to furnish returns in respect of receipts from contract works for sales tax assessment.

anchor.surface_text: Acting on these provisions, the authorities companystituted under the Act called upon the companytractors within the State to furnish returns in respect of their receipts from companytract works for the purpose of assessment of sales tax, to which the appellants replied by instituting the proceedings,

facts.text: Appellants in CA 254 are Jabalpur Contractors Association and certain contractors, filed M.P. No. 279 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 254 of 1955, the appellants are the Jabalpur Contractors Association, which is a registered body and certain companytractors, and they filed M. P. No. 279 of 1954 questioning the validity of the proposed assessment on the same grounds as in M. P. No. 245 of 1954.

facts.text: Appellant in CA 255 is Madhya Pradesh Contractors Association, Nagpur, filed M.P. No. 308 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in Civil Appeal No. 255 of 1955, is the Madhya Pradesh Contractors Association, Nagpur, which is again a registered body, and it filed M. P. 305 of 1954, challenging the legality of the proceedings for assessment on the same grounds as in M. P. No. 245 of 1954.

facts.text: Nagpur High Court by judgment dated November 30, 1954 held that sale of goods in Entry 48 covers transactions where property passes for money, including materials in building contracts; provisions valid but s.2(h)(ii) and Rule 4 ultra vires; notification September 18, 1950 valid.

anchor.surface_text: All these three petitions were heard together, and by their judgment dated November 30, 1954, the learned Judges held that the expression sale of goods in Entry 48 was wide enough to companyerall transactions in which property in the moveables passed from one person to another for money, and that, accordingly, in a building companytract there was a sale within Entry 48 of the materials used therein, and that the provisions of the Act imposing tax thereon were valid. But the learned Judges also held that the tax companyld be levied only on the actual value of the materials to be determined on an enquiry into the matter, and that the definition of price in s. 2  h  and r. 4 framed pursuant thereto were ultra vires in that they laid down artificial rules for fixing the same by deducting certain percentages from out of the total receipts on account of labour. As regards the numberification dated September 18, 1950, the learned Judges held that it was within the authority companyferred by the statute and was valid.

facts.text: State Government issued notification on September 18, 1950 amending item 33 of Schedule II by substituting 'Goods sold by the State Government' for 'Goods sold to or by the State Government'.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the power companyferred by s. 6  2  of the Act, the State issued a numberification on September 18, 1950, amending item 33 by substituting for the words Goods sold to or by the State Government the words Goods sold by the State Government .

facts.text: Item 33 in Sch. II originally 'Goods sold by the Crown', amended by Act XVI of 1949 to 'Goods sold to or by the Crown', then by Adaptation Order of 1950 to 'State Government'.

anchor.surface_text: Item 33 in Sch. 11 as originally enacted was Goods sold by the Crown . This was amended by Act XVI of 1949 by substituting for the above words Goods sold to or by the Crown . By an Adaptation Order of 1950, the words State Government were substituted for Crown, and item 33 became Goods sold to or by the State Government

facts.text: Petitioners contended that Provincial Legislature had no authority under Entry 48 List II Sch. VII Govt of India Act 1935 to tax supply of materials in works contracts as it is not sale of goods.

anchor.surface_text: He companytended firstly that the Provincial Legislature had authority under Entry 48 of List 11, Sch. VII of the Government of India Act, 1935, to impose tax only on sale of goods, that the supply of materials in works companytracts was number a sale within that Entry, and that the provisions of the Act, which sought to impose a tax thereon treating it as a sale, were therefore ultra vires

facts.text: Petitioners contended entitled to exemption under item 33 Sch. II as per Act XVI of 1949, and notification Sept 18 1950 withdrawing exemption for sales to government unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: and secondly that he was entitled to exemption under item 33 in Sch. 11 to the Act as enacted by Act XVI of 1949, and that the numberification of the Government dated September 18, 1950, withdrawing that exemption was unconstitutional and void.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that in a building contract there is no sale of materials as such, following State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley, provisions ultra vires under Entry 48.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the first companytention, the question is number companycluded by the decision of this Court in The State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co.  Madras  Ltd.  1  in which it has been held that the expression sale of goods in Entry 48 has the same meaning which it has in the Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930, that in a building companytract there is numbersale of materials as such, and that it is therefore ultra vires the powers of the Provincial Legislature to impose tax on the supply of materials.

facts.text: Supreme Court held notification dated September 18, 1950 valid, not unconstitutional delegation.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that the power companyferred on the State Government by s. 6 2  to amend the schedule relating to exemption is in companysonance with the accepted legislative practice relating to the topic, and is number unconstitutional.

facts.text: State of Madhya Pradesh, State of Bombay, State of Punjab intervened.

anchor.surface_text: Sen, S. B. Sen and 1. N. Shroff, for the respondents in A. Nos. 253 and 254 of 1950 and for the State of Madhya Pradesh  Intervener . K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India and R. H. Dhebar, for the respondents in C. A. No. 255 of 1955 and for the State of Bombay  Intervener . S. Bindra and T. M. Sen, for the State of Punjab  Intervener .

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art. 132(1) of Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this judgment that the above appeals have been preferred on a certificate granted by the High Court under Art. 132 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Bose J. delivered a separate judgment agreeing except not expressing opinion on s.6(2) power.

anchor.surface_text: BOSE J.-I agree except that I prefer number to express an opinion about the validity of the power companyferred on the State Government by s. 6 2  of the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947, to amend the schedule in the way in which it has been amended here.

facts.text: Supreme Court directed to restrain respondents from enforcing Act provisions on construction works contracts that are single and indivisible.

anchor.surface_text: But on our finding on the first question that the impugned provisions of the Act are ultra vires the powers of the Provincial Legislature under Entry 48 in List 11 in the seventh Schedule, we should set aside the orders of the Court below, and direct that the respondents be restrained from enforcing the provisions of the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947, in so far as they seek to impose a tax on companystruction works.

holdings.text: the expression sale of goods in Entry 48 has the same meaning which it has in the Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930, that in a building contract there is no sale of materials as such, and that it is therefore ultra vires the powers of the Provincial Legislature to impose tax on the supply of materials.

anchor.surface_text: in which it has been held that the expression sale of goods in Entry 48 has the same meaning which it has in the Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930, that in a building contract there is no sale of materials as such, and that it is therefore ultra vires the powers of the Provincial Legislature to impose tax on the supply of materials.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bound by precedent in State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co. (Madras) Ltd. applying definition of sale from Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930 to Entry 48.

holdings.text: when a question arises as to whether a particular works contract could be charged to sales tax, it will be for the authorities under the Act to determine whether the agreement in question is, on its true construction, a combination of an agreement to sell and an agreement to work, and if they come to the conclusion that such is its character, then it will be open to them to proceed against that part of it which is a contract for the sale of goods, and impose tax thereon.

anchor.surface_text: when a question arises as to whether a particular works contract could be charged to sales tax, it will be for the authorities under the Act to determine whether the agreement in question is, on its true construction, a combination of an agreement to sell and an agreement to work, and if they come to the conclusion that such is its character, then it will be open to them to proceed against that part of it which is a contract for the sale of goods, and impose tax thereon.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Correct legal position as observed in State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co. (Madras) Ltd.; authorities to investigate true nature of contract.

holdings.text: the power conferred on the State Government by s. 6(2) to amend the schedule relating to exemption is in consonance with the accepted legislative practice relating to the topic, and is not unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that the power conferred on the State Government by s. 6 2  to amend the schedule relating to exemption is in consonance with the accepted legislative practice relating to the topic, and is not unconstitutional.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent with precedents like Powell v. Apollo Candle Company, Syed Mohamed v. State of Madras, Hampton v. United States on delegation in taxation laws.

holdings.text: The two sub-sections together form integral parts of a single enactment, the object of which is to grant exemption from taxation in respect of such goods and to such extent as may from time to time be determined by the State Government. Section 6(1), therefore, cannot have an operation independent of s. 6(2), and an exemption granted thereunder is conditional and subject to any modification that might be issued under s. 6(2).

anchor.surface_text: But that, in our opinion, is not the correct interpretation of the section. The two sub- sections together form integral parts of a single enactment, the object of which is to grant exemption from taxation in respect of such goods and to such extent as may from time to time be determined by the State Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of ss. 6(1) and 6(2) as integral parts granting conditional exemption subject to amendment.

holdings.text: the impugned provisions of the Act are ultra vires the powers of the Provincial Legislature under Entry 48 in List II in the seventh Schedule... direct that the respondents be restrained from enforcing the provisions of the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947, in so far as they seek to impose a tax on construction works.

anchor.surface_text: But on our finding on the first question that the impugned provisions of the Act are ultra vires the powers of the Provincial Legislature under Entry 48 in List 11 in the seventh Schedule, we should set aside the orders of the Court below, and direct that the respondents be restrained from enforcing the provisions of the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947, in so far as they seek to impose a tax on construction works.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of holding on Entry 48 to facts; set aside lower court orders and issue restraint.

holdings.text: the prohibition against imposition of tax is only in respect of contracts which are single and indivisible and not of contracts which are a combination of distinct contracts for sale of materials and for work, and that nothing that we have said in this judgment shall bar the sales tax authorities from deciding whether a particular contract falls within one category or the other and imposing a tax on the agreement of sale of materials, where the contract belongs to the latter category.

anchor.surface_text: It should be made clear, however, in accordance with what we have already stated, that the prohibition against imposition of tax is only in respect of contracts which are single and indivisible and not of contracts which are a combination of distinct contracts for sale of materials and for work, and that nothing that we have said in this judgment shall bar the sales tax authorities from deciding whether a particular contract falls within one category or the other and imposing a tax on the agreement of sale of materials, where the contract belongs to the latter category.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clarification consistent with prior holdings on indivisible vs. composite contracts.

anchor.surface_text: While a power to execute a law, it was argued, companyld be delegated to the executive, the power to make it must be exercised by the Legislature itself, and reliance was placed on the observations in Hampton J R Co. United States  2 , Panama Refining Co. v. Ryan  3 , and Schechter v. United States  4 , as supporting this position.

precedents.case_name: Schechter Poultry Corp. v. United States
precedents.cited_proposition: power to make law cannot be delegated to executive

precedents.citation: re The Delhi Laws Act, 1912 etc.  1

anchor.surface_text: that, in consequence, the impugned notification was bad in that, in reversal of the policy laid down by the legislature in Act XVI of 1949 that sales to Government should be excluded from the operation of the Act, it withdrew the exemption which had been granted thereunder, and the observations in re The Delhi Laws Act, 1912 etc.  1 , and the decision in Rajnarain Singh v. The Chairman, Patna Administration Committee, Patna and another  2 , were strongly relied on as establishing this contention.

precedents.case_name: In re The Delhi Laws Act, 1912
precedents.cited_proposition: limits on delegation of legislative power

precedents.citation: Rajnarain Singh v. The Chairman, Patna Administration Committee, Patna and another  2

anchor.surface_text: and the observations in re The Delhi Laws Act, 1912 etc.  1 , and the decision in Rajnarain Singh v. The Chairman, Patna Administration Committee, Patna and another  2 , were strongly relied on as establishing this contention. Mr. N. C. Chatterjee particularly relied on the following observations of Bose J. at p. 301 in Rajnarain Singhs case  2  In our opinion, the majority view was that an executive authority can be authorised to modify either existing or future laws but not in any essential feature.

precedents.case_name: Rajnarain Singh v. Chairman, Patna Administration Committee
precedents.cited_proposition: executive authority can modify laws but not in any essential feature or change of policy
precedents.cited_holding: it cannot include a change of policy

precedents.citation: Powell v. Appollo Candle Company Limited

anchor.surface_text: Now, the authorities are clear that it is not unconstitutional for the legislature to leave it to the executive to determine details relating to the working of taxation laws, such as the selection of persons on whom the tax is to be laid, the rates at which it is to be charged in respect of different classes of goods, and the like. In Powell v. Appollo Candle Company Limited the question arose as to whether s. 133 of the Customs Regulation Act of 1879 of New South Wales which conferred a power on the Governor to impose tax on certain articles of import was an unconstitutional delegation of legislative powers.

precedents.case_name: Powell v. Apollo Candle Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: delegation to executive to determine details of taxation laws like rates is permissible
precedents.cited_holding: the duties levied under the Order-in-Council are really levied by the authority of the Act; Legislature has not parted with its perfect control

precedents.citation: Syed Mohamed Co. v. The State of Madras  1

anchor.surface_text: In Syed Mohamed Co. v. The State of Madras  1 , the question was as to the vires of rules 4 and 16 framed under the Madras General Sales Tax Act. Section 5  vi  of that Act had left it to the rule-making authority to determine at which single point in the series of sales by successive dealers the tax should be levied, and pursuant thereto, rules 4 and 16 had provided that it was the purchaser who was liable to pay the tax in respect of sales of hides and skins.

precedents.case_name: Syed Mohamed & Co. v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: delegation to determine at which single point in the series of sales the tax should be levied is valid
precedents.cited_holding: the delegation of authority under s. 5(vi) was within permissible constitutional limits

precedents.citation: Hampton J. R. Co. v. United States  2
precedents.case_name: Hampton, J.R. Co. v. United States
precedents.cited_proposition: power given to President to approve increases or decreases in rates of duty to carry out policies declared in statute is not unconstitutional delegation

justification_sets.label: Works Contract Doctrine (Gannon Dunkerley Principle) support

anchor.surface_text: But on our finding on the first question that the impugned provisions of the Act are ultra vires the powers of the Provincial Legislature under Entry 48 in List 11 in the seventh Schedule, we should set aside the orders of the Court below, and direct that the respondents be restrained from enforcing the provisions of the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947, in so far as they seek to impose a tax on construction works. It should be made clear, however, in accordance with what we have already stated, that the prohibition against imposition of tax is only in respect of contracts which are single and indivisible and not of contracts which are a combination of distinct contracts for sale of materials and for work, and that nothing that we have said in this judgment shall bar the sales tax authorities from deciding whether a particular contract falls within one category or the other and imposing a tax on the agreement of sale of materials, where the contract belongs to the latter category.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court judgment set aside; provisions of the Act held ultra vires for imposing tax on materials in single and indivisible construction works contracts; restraint on enforcement for such contracts; notification upheld; sales tax possible on divisible contracts.
directions: Set aside the orders of the Court below.
Respondents restrained from enforcing the provisions of the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947, insofar as they seek to impose tax on construction works.
Prohibition applies only to single and indivisible contracts; sales tax authorities may determine nature of contract and tax sale of materials portion if divisible.
Parties to bear their own costs throughout.

But on our finding on the first question that the impugned provisions of the Act are ultra vires the powers of the Provincial Legislature under Entry 48 in List 11 in the seventh Schedule, we should set aside the orders of the Court below, and direct that the respondents be restrained from enforcing the provisions of the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947, in so far as they seek to impose a tax on construction works. It should be made clear, however, in accordance with what we have already stated, that the prohibition against imposition of tax is only in respect of contracts which are single and indivisible and not of contracts which are a combination of distinct contracts for sale of materials and for work, and that nothing that we have said in this judgment shall bar the sales tax authorities from deciding whether a particular contract falls within one category or the other and imposing a tax on the agreement of sale of materials, where the contract belongs to the latter category.

anchor.surface_text: when a question arises as to whether a particular works contract could be charged to sales tax, it will be for the authorities under the Act to determine whether the agreement in question is, on its true construction, a combination of an agreement to sell and an agreement to work, and if they come to the conclusion that such is its character, then it will be open to them to proceed against that part of it which is a contract for the sale of goods, and impose tax thereon.

But on our finding on the first question that the impugned provisions of the Act are ultra vires the powers of the Provincial Legislature under Entry 48 in List 11 in the seventh Schedule, we should set aside the orders of the Court below, and direct that the respondents be restrained from enforcing the provisions of the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947, in so far as they seek to impose a tax on construction works. anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that the power conferred on the State Government by s. 6 2  to amend the schedule relating to exemption is in consonance with the accepted legislative practice relating to the topic, and is not unconstitutional.

But on our finding on the first question that the impugned provisions of the Act are ultra vires the powers of the Provincial Legislature under Entry 48 in List 11 in the seventh Schedule, we should set aside the orders of the Court below, and direct that the respondents be restrained from enforcing the provisions of the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947, in so far as they seek to impose a tax on construction works. anchor.surface_text: But that, in our opinion, is not the correct interpretation of the section. The two sub- sections together form integral parts of a single enactment, the object of which is to grant exemption from taxation in respect of such goods and to such extent as may from time to time be determined by the State Government.

But on our finding on the first question that the impugned provisions of the Act are ultra vires the powers of the Provincial Legislature under Entry 48 in List 11 in the seventh Schedule, we should set aside the orders of the Court below, and direct that the respondents be restrained from enforcing the provisions of the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947, in so far as they seek to impose a tax on construction works. It should be made clear, however, in accordance with what we have already stated, that the prohibition against imposition of tax is only in respect of contracts which are single and indivisible and not of contracts which are a combination of distinct contracts for sale of materials and for work, and that nothing that we have said in this judgment shall bar the sales tax authorities from deciding whether a particular contract falls within one category or the other and imposing a tax on the agreement of sale of materials, where the contract belongs to the latter category.
